revision.text:
'''Zenia Mucha''' (born 1957) is an American businesswoman and the Senior Executive Vice President and [[Chief Communications Officer]] of [[The Walt Disney Company]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2017/11/critics-to-disney-time-to-grow-up|title=Critics to Disney: Time to Grow Up|last=Keegan|first=Rebecca|website=HWD|language=en|access-date=2019-05-05}}</ref> Mucha reports to chairman and chief executive officer [[Bob Iger]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thewaltdisneycompany.com/leaders/zenia-mucha/|title=Zenia Mucha|website=The Walt Disney Company|language=en-US|access-date=2019-05-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2019/01/disney-ceo-bob-igers-pay-rises-80-to-65-7-million-1202533947/|title=Disney CEO Bob Iger’s Pay Rises 80% To $65.7 Million|last=Chmielewski|first=Dawn C.|last2=Chmielewski|first2=Dawn C.|date=2019-01-11|website=Deadline|language=en|access-date=2019-05-05}}</ref> Mucha previously worked in [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican politics]] and was described as "the most powerful woman in New York state."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pagesix.com/2007/01/08/power-queen-breakup-blues/|title=POWER QUEEN BREAKUP BLUES|last=Staff|first=PageSix com|date=2007-01-08|website=Page Six|language=en|access-date=2019-05-05}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Mucha was born in [[Poland]] to Ukrainian parents who spent time in work camps in [[Nazi Germany]]. She immigrated to [[New York City]] at age 9. Mucha graduated from the lower East side St. George Ukrainian Catholic School. Mucha studied political science at [[Brooklyn College]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/06/nyregion/for-pataki-a-gruff-protector-communications-chief-is-also-influential-adviser.html|title=For Pataki, a Gruff Protector; Communications Chief Is Also Influential Adviser|last=Sack|first=Kevin|date=1995-03-06|work=The New York Times|access-date=2019-05-05|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
== Career == Mucha began her professional career in politics, serving as communications director and campaign manager for [[U.S. senator|U.S. Senator]] [[Al D'Amato]]. She took leaves to work on the campaigns of [[Ronald Reagan]] and [[George H. W. Bush]]. She later worked as the director of communications and as an influential senior policy advisor to [[Governor of New York]] [[George Pataki]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prweek.com/article/1279370/newsmaker-zenia-mucha-walt-disney-company|title=Newsmaker: Zenia Mucha, The Walt Disney Company|last=Casey|first=Bernadette|website=www.prweek.com|access-date=2019-05-05}}</ref>
Mucha joined the Walt Disney Company in 2001, as Senior Vice President of Communications for the ABC Broadcast Group and the [[American Broadcasting Company]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.holmesreport.com/ranking-and-data/influence-100/the-influence-100-2018/profiles/zenia-mucha|title=Zenia Mucha|website=www.holmesreport.com|language=en|access-date=2019-05-05}}</ref>
Since 2002, Mucha has led communications for all of Disney’s strategic business initiatives including the acquisitions of [[Pixar]], [[Marvel Entertainment|Marvel]] and [[Lucasfilm]]. Under Mucha's leadership, Disney launched [[D23 (Disney)|D23]], the first-ever official Disney fan club, with members in 50 U.S. states and 35 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=c8042ef0-6ec9-11e9-b92e-9dcd1281918d&url=L3Jlc2VhcmNoL3N0b2Nrcy9wZW9wbGUvcGVyc29uLmFzcD9wZXJzb25JZD01NTIzNTA4JnByaXZjYXBJZD0xOTE1NjQ=|title=Bloomberg - Zenia Mucha|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2019-05-05}}</ref>
== Awards == In 2012, Mucha received the Matrix Award from New York Women in Communications. In 2017, she was inducted into the [[PRWeek]] Hall of Fame.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ukrainianinstitutenyc.wordpress.com/2012/11/14/an-evening-with-zenia-mucha/|title=An Evening with ZENIA MUCHA|date=2012-11-14|website=Ukrainian Institute of America|language=en|access-date=2019-05-05}}</ref>
